utterances: We reported here yesterday on the formal declassification and release of the Pentagon Papers and we spoke with the man who leaked that compilation of documents about the war in Vietnam back in June 1971, Daniel Ellsberg.
Vietnam is a fiasco for 30 years, essentially, that would not have stood the light of public discussion if, I think, the very documents in the Pentagon Papers had been available during that time.
Well, today, another voice on the Pentagon Papers - the man who was assigned by Defense Secretary Robert McNamara to compile them, Leslie Gelb.

Before he became a New York Times correspondent and columnist, before he became an assistant secretary of state in the Carter administration and president of the Council on Foreign Relations, Les Gelb was director of Policy Planning at the Defense Department from 1967 until 1969.
He joins us now from New York, welcome.
Thank you, Robert.
And tell me first about the assignment you got, to put together what came to be known as the Pentagon Papers.
Well, in June '67, I was asked to put together a group of six people to answer a hundred handwritten questions about the Vietnam War.

They were questions like how do we know that the kill count is accurate, not made up; how do we know that the Strategic Hamlet Program is effective; how do we know that pacification could work; what about the effectiveness of bombing.
These are all the questions you would ask if you went to a Pentagon press briefing.
And the group of six and I got together and talked about it.
And I sent a memo to McNamara, saying we could answer these questions the way they're always answered at press conferences and do it in less than three months.
But if you want us to answer them seriously, we'd have to sequester some documents and do some studies and then get back to you - and here are the kinds of studies we would do.
And at that point, McNamara approved the monographs that were to become the Pentagon Papers, and said write them and let the chips fall where they may.

Now, we should just point out here that the kind of questions that you mentioned, in addition to being - as you say - news conference questions, tough ones, were also - this was the stuff of what people were asking and saying at teach-ins and the antiwar movement in the United States, in all the polemics about the Vietnam War, people were arguing about these things.
What, as you understood it, what was the point?
What did McNamara want to with your - what turned out to be - voluminous answers to his questions?
The truth is we didn't know.
And to this day, I tell you, even though I've talked to McNamara about this enterprise many times, I still don't know.
Ellsberg reads this lesson into the Pentagon Papers.
He says it demonstrates that the U.S.
was lying and duplicitous about how we got involved in Vietnam; if the public had known about those lies - and he would count as a lie, not say the story of the Gulf of Tonkin, that U.S.
warships had been attacked, but the certainty with which it was said that U.S.
warships were attacked and the justification for military action.
He says if all of that had been known, the Vietnam War never would've happened.
I just disagree with him profoundly because while there were lies, I don't know of a war were there weren't lies - the two go together.

Western Shelter Systems was just one of hundreds of companies that found themselves the sudden beneficiaries of no-bid contracts this month, contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
FEMA's purchasing guidelines say the agency is supposed to line up contracts in advance so the details are already worked out when they need to place an order.
In this case, though, according to documents, FEMA was lining up most of its emergency supplies after the storm.
FEMA's purchasing department became so overwhelmed, they then asked another federal agency, the General Services Administration, for help.

Among the essential items needed: $2 million worth of ready-to-eat meals, $92,000 worth of Gerber baby food, half a million dollars worth of medical supplies and hundreds of other items, all purchased without bidding.
Former FEMA Director Michael Brown told Congress this week he couldn't explain why they had to spend $200,000 at the last minute for body bags at the full price.
I don't know, and that was a mistake, one that we should look at and make sure we don't do in the future.
We should've had the contract in place before Katrina made landfall.
The documents show FEMA was scrambling for ice, long an agency mainstay.
Ice is used to keep medicine fresh and bodies from decomposing.
But Michael Brown said he doesn't think providing ice is essential.
I don't think that's a federal government responsibility to provide ice to keep my hamburger meat in my freezer or refrigerator fresh.
According to an audit a year ago, FEMA's procurement office was a mess.
Only one of 45 employees could document they had fulfilled the requirements to be a government purchaser.
The report also found that the department was using a 12-year-old manual that relied on a law that was repealed in 1996.
FEMA couldn't have anticipated all the expenses, but Clark Kent Ervin, the former inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security, says most of the no-bid contracts are inexcusable.
There were so many no-bid contracts that money was wasted that could have been better spent, and that adequate supplies were not prepositioned.
But Ervin says there's also a bigger problem that needs to be resolved.
FEMA didn't have the money that it needed in order to be adequately prepared, but FEMA is not unique in that regard.
You know, I'm a conservative Republican and so I'm not one who reflexively supports the notion of more government spending.
On the other hand, part of the problem is that we have tried to do homeland security on the cheap since day one.
Over the coming months, billions more will be spent on contracts for Hurricane Katrina.
The Department of Homeland Security says they have 60 auditors on hand reviewing FEMA's purchases.
Laura Sullivan, NPR News, Washington.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED for NPR News.
I'm Melissa Block.
Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez has accepted his first electoral defeat after voters narrowly rejected sweeping constitutional changes that would have greatly expanded his powers.
Chavez told reporters in Caracas today that the outcome shows - in his words - that Venezuelan democracy is maturing.
He added: there is no dictatorship here.
The referendum was defeated by a vote of 51 to 49 percent.
It would have eliminated term limits, allowing Chavez to run for reelection indefinitely.
And it would have granted the socialist president broad, new powers over the economy and property.
To talk about what this defeat means for Chavez and for Venezuela, Margarita Lopez-Maya joins us by phone from Caracas.
She's a professor of political history at the Central University of Venezuela.
Welcome to the program.
Well, thank you very much for inviting me.
I gather that you have been a Chavez supporter in the past, but you were opposed to this referendum.
Were you surprised by the result?
I guess everybody was kind of surprised by it.
Even, it's difficult to believe that Chavez could be defeated after having such an overwhelming victory a year ago.
Well, what does it say do you think that this referendum did go down?
Yes.
Well, I think it says a lot of interesting things.
In the first part, I think it says that what we call the Chavismo is just not accepting anything Chavez says.
I think this was a very clear message to Chavez from people that have supported him before.
Usually people have this thought that Chavez is a charismatic leader and that everybody follows him like sheep.
So it wasn't - it didn't work out that way.
Do you think people were afraid of expanding dictatorship in Venezuela?
Well, I think one of the things that we - the people were very uncomfortable was with the reelection.
That there would be no term limits, in other words?
Yes.
Yes, because this history of my country as usual - that isn't in Latin America - we have now many dictators and calvicios(ph) that have changed the constitution in order to stay in power.
So this was a struggle for - to take the side of democracy in the 20th century and this was like a regression.

Do you think that Hugo Chavez has to worry now about a galvanized opposition, a coalition of students and clergy leaders and business leaders who came together, and that he has to worry about maybe in a way that he didn't have to before?

Well, honestly, I don't think this was a matter too much of the opposition, even though the opposition did a good job - was able to unite and was able to present the funds and play by the rules of the game.
I think this was much more the result of discomfort inside Chavismo.
And I think what he has to really worry about is to how to put again - to unite his people because this brought a lot of discontent.

McNamara leaves the Pentagon and is succeeded by Clark Clifford, one of the wise old men of the Democratic Party at the time and close to Lyndon Johnson, and he inherits this entire project.
